summary:
Did you think they did it alone?
Built whole armies, and conquered thrones?
Constructed promised lands that would outlive the...
body:
Did you think they did it alone?

Built whole armies, and conquered thrones?

Constructed promised lands that would outlive the sun?

Resurrected prosperity from ash and bone?

A crest is not just a man made thing, it is also created by a generation of women who wield swords through guile and letters.

Show me your Kings, and I will show you the Queens that willed them, that bred them, that taught them to do better.

-Of Kings And Queens

summary: I will never get over how enraged Jon’s face was in the crypt scene with Littlefinger. Mind you, a lot of awful shit has...
body:
I will never get over how enraged Jon’s face was in the crypt scene with Littlefinger. Mind you, a lot of awful shit has happened to Jon in the past seven seasons of Game of Thrones but Jon has NEVER reacted so violently to anyone else in the show! There is literally no previous scene that you can compare his rage too. When that scene came out and after season 7 aired there were a lot of people who were not only upset about the writing in season 7, but specifically upset about that particular scene with Jon. Many believed that Jon’s reaction to Littlefinger was so out of character and that it didn’t make sense for Jon to react so violently to Littlefinger. Also many people thought it was an injustice to Littlefinger. For a character as smart and strategic as he was people couldn’t wrap their mind around why he would blantanly provoke Jon and reveal his feelings for Sansa. They couldn’t understand what he was trying to accomplish.

The funny thing is that the criticism this scene has received is ABSOLUTELY VALID! Yes, Jon is protective of Sansa but based on the Jon we’ve seen in the show, his reaction was abnormal and extremely out of character. Also Littlefinger isn’t usually so blatant with his manipulations and emotions. He’s usually pretty tactful. With that being said, that’s why I think this scene was the biggest tell-tale sign that Jon has deeper feelings for Sansa than he realizes. Make no mistake, the crypt scene was not filler for season 7! Littlefinger wasn’t just “poking the bear” for no reason. I believe that scene was created to further push this story along to where it will eventually lead. The purpose of that scene wasn’t to highlight the danger/threat of Littlefinger to Jon and Sansa’s relationship. We knew Littlefinger was a threat from season 6. The purpose of this scene was to REVEAL feelings/weaknesses hidden underneath the surface. Jon’s violent reaction was the entire point of that scene. It was something that we as an audience were immediately supposed to take notice of.

Another point that I want to mention is this. In the history of this show have you ever seen Littlefinger look confused?! Have you ever seen him look bewildered like he didn’t know what just happened? His excecution aside, Littlefinger has definitely been caught off guard before but he’s never had a look of confusion. He usually has the upper hand in scenes often manipulating the individual he’s speaking to and privy to their secrets. But this time around in this particular scene that wasn’t the case. For the first time Littlefinger seems dumbfounded by the events that occurred until “something” dawns on him and he stares at Sansa.

summary:
Last night I dreamt that Jon Snow was trying to save Santa Claus and I was a pirate running around with Jon Snows backpack.
How...
body:
Last night I dreamt that Jon Snow was trying to save Santa Claus and I was a pirate running around with Jon Snows backpack.

How did I know it was his ? It was Army style and had his name on a patch across the front. Had to hide it behind a giant curtain though. Obviously.

🤷

summary: The Starks and the Children of the Forest
title: The Starks and the Children of the Forest
body:
Today I’ll discuss a theory that I’ve come up with very recently. Well, I actually came up with it two hours ago and I’m curious about what you may think about this theory. So, let’s jump right in.  

“There must always be a Stark in Winterfell.” But why? 

We have heard this particular line plenty of times over the past seven seasons and for some reason, it has always stuck with me. Not because it is not the official Stark motto and was still used frequently, but because of the seriousness with which it is always uttered.

Lately, I have been re-watching the TV series and the way Catelyn Stark says it, with a grave face and in with a serious tone, it makes me wonder if there is a deeper significance to it than it just being a mere belief or a good luck charm. 

I mean, we all have beliefs and our families have certain customs and traditions that are being followed for generations but traditions may change after a long time, say after 100, 200 or 300 years if the descendants of the family feel that the traditions do not go hand-in-hand with the way society works. 

House Stark is one of the oldest houses of Westeros, founded by Brandon ‘The Builder’ Stark sometime after the first Long Night. Yet even 1000s of years later, the words are still significant and are uttered in a way as though lives depend on it. 

Does it have anything to do with the White Walker and the Night King? 

We know that Brandon the Builder overlooked the construction of the Wall and Winterfell after the Long Night. The Wall was created with the help of the Children of the Forest who used some kind of magic to restrict the dead to the north of the Wall.  

But I wonder if they did it on their own accord. Or were they asked for help?

What if the Children were asked for help by Brandon the Builder? Brandon must have known about the magical gifts the Children posses. What if he asked them to help him construct the wall?

Well, we know that the Wall does possess magical properties and so the Children definitely helped. But did they entirely?

I believe that they cursed House Stark and Winterfell in the weirdest way which only restricted them from taking family vacations.

Remember that the Wall was made after the Long Night while The Pact between the Children and the First Men was made some 4000 years earlier- the Pact which was signed after a brutal war between the children and the first men. A war which, though I’m not sure, probably made the children fear extinction. How can I say that? Well, I do believe that when the Children created the Night King, it was their last major move, the last ace up their sleeves. So they must be losing at the time and probably got reduced in number. 

Come the Long Night, that number would have gone down even further when compared to the First Men’s population. So, I believe that when Brandon Stark, a descendant of the First Men, asked the Children to help construct the wall, a move which would have ensured the First Men’s survival for ages to come, they got angry at the thought of it.

Because even though a pact was signed, Brandon’s ancestors did kill the Children’s ancestors and so maybe it offended them that Brandon asked them for help to ensure the safety of ‘his’ people. So they helped Brandon in creating the wall, but they also cursed him and his family and their home in Winterfell. Maybe just out of spite. 

What was the curse? 

I believe that they did some magic on the Wall and linked it to Winterfell and the Stark bloodline in a way that if the Starks ever left Winterfell, the magic done on the Wall would be undone and the dead would be able to pass.   

Because to be honest, in a situation of the Starks ever leaving Winterfell and the dead returning, it would have meant the extinction of the Children, but more importantly for them, it would have meant the extinction of the civilisation which destroyed theirs. It could have been a move just out of a feeling of revenge. There may not have been many children left after the Long Night and so their loss would not have been anywhere as much as the First Men’s descendants. 

I believe that the FM’s extinction would have served the Children’s ego well as their extinction would have come because of them, the beings that they wanted to finish in the first place.

But then how did the words, “There must always be a Stark in Winterfell” happened? Why would the Children give up the secret to their magic? 

Maybe because their consciousness didn’t allow them to just walk away without warning the Starks. Or maybe they just wanted to rub it in the Starks’ face that if the dead ever come back, it would be because of them.

But then, you could ask, why did we see the WW in the first episode? The Starks were still in Winterfell, the magic would have still been there.

Well, there is a wide belief that the NK can see in the past and in the future like Bran. We’ve not see Bran see the future yet but I believe that the NK must have more powers and also more control over those powers in comparison to a semi-pro Three-Eyed-Raven. So he would have known for a long time that all the Starks would eventually leave Winterfell under different circumstances. 

And he was waiting, ready to strike!

Lately, I have been re-watching the TV series and the way Catelyn Stark says it, with a grave face and in with a serious tone, it makes me wonder if there is a deeper significance to it than it just being a mere belief or a good luck charm. 

I mean, we all have beliefs and our families have certain customs and traditions that are being followed for generations but traditions may change after a long time, say after 100, 200 or 300 years if the descendants of the family feel that the traditions do not go hand-in-hand with the way society works. 

House Stark is one of the oldest houses of Westeros, founded by Brandon ‘The Builder’ Stark sometime after the first Long Night. Yet even 1000s of years later, the words are still significant and are uttered in a way as though lives depend on it. 

Does it have anything to do with the White Walker and the Night King? 

We know that Brandon the Builder overlooked the construction of the Wall and Winterfell after the Long Night. The Wall was created with the help of the Children of the Forest who used some kind of magic to restrict the dead to the north of the Wall.  

But I wonder if they did it on their own accord. Or were they asked for help?

What if the Children were asked for help by Brandon the Builder? Brandon must have known about the magical gifts the Children posses. What if he asked them to help him construct the wall?

Well, we know that the Wall does possess magical properties and so the Children definitely helped. But did they entirely?

I believe that they cursed House Stark and Winterfell in the weirdest way which only restricted them from taking family vacations.

Remember that the Wall was made after the Long Night while The Pact between the Children and the First Men was made some 4000 years earlier- the Pact which was signed after a brutal war between the children and the first men. A war which, though I’m not sure, probably made the children fear extinction. How can I say that? Well, I do believe that when the Children created the Night King, it was their last major move, the last ace up their sleeves. So they must be losing at the time and probably got reduced in number. 

Come the Long Night, that number would have gone down even further when compared to the First Men’s population. So, I believe that when Brandon Stark, a descendant of the First Men, asked the Children to help construct the wall, a move which would have ensured the First Men’s survival for ages to come, they got angry at the thought of it.

Because even though a pact was signed, Brandon’s ancestors did kill the Children’s ancestors and so maybe it offended them that Brandon asked them for help to ensure the safety of ‘his’ people. So they helped Brandon in creating the wall, but they also cursed him and his family and their home in Winterfell. Maybe just out of spite. 

What was the curse? 

I believe that they did some magic on the Wall and linked it to Winterfell and the Stark bloodline in a way that if the Starks ever left Winterfell, the magic done on the Wall would be undone and the dead would be able to pass.   

Because to be honest, in a situation of the Starks ever leaving Winterfell and the dead returning, it would have meant the extinction of the Children, but more importantly for them, it would have meant the extinction of the civilisation which destroyed theirs. It could have been a move just out of a feeling of revenge. There may not have been many children left after the Long Night and so their loss would not have been anywhere as much as the First Men’s descendants. 

I believe that the FM’s extinction would have served the Children’s ego well as their extinction would have come because of them, the beings that they wanted to finish in the first place.

But then how did the words, “There must always be a Stark in Winterfell” happened? Why would the Children give up the secret to their magic? 

Maybe because their consciousness didn’t allow them to just walk away without warning the Starks. Or maybe they just wanted to rub it in the Starks’ face that if the dead ever come back, it would be because of them.

But then, you could ask, why did we see the WW in the first episode? The Starks were still in Winterfell, the magic would have still been there.

Well, there is a wide belief that the NK can see in the past and in the future like Bran. We’ve not see Bran see the future yet but I believe that the NK must have more powers and also more control over those powers in comparison to a semi-pro Three-Eyed-Raven. So he would have known for a long time that all the Starks would eventually leave Winterfell under different circumstances. 

And he was waiting, ready to strike!

summary: If book!Jon is also reanimated by Melissandre, would that mean that he is now freed from his vows and that he could marry Val...
question: If book!Jon is also reanimated by Melissandre, would that mean that he is now freed from his vows and that he could marry Val and claim Winterfell (i'm fully aware this won't happen, but would that be possible?)
answer:
Depends. Does the Watch put more weight on the vows being for life? In which case, Jon is alive, and his vows hold. Or does the Watch put more weight on a Watchman’s watch not ending until their death? In which case, notwithstanding Jon’s subsequent resurrection, his vows have expired, his membership in the order is terminated, and he can do what he likes with his life.

There’s not exactly precedent for this one.

Davos EXPECTED Jon to do SOMETHING to Theon. If he was...
body:
So.. rewatching this scene, I think I’ve come to realize what happened.

Davos EXPECTED Jon to do SOMETHING to Theon. If he was so worried about Jon acting up. He would have held him back right away when he started to move forward towards Theon.

Then, when Jon DIDN’T. It shocked Davos.

Cause let’s be real here, is the weight of ALL Theon did, worth being ignored by helping Sansa? To some, it definitely isn’t. Theon was the MAIN reason why Winterfell was taken, its inhabitants killed and he was the reason why Bran and Rickon had to run, ultimately getting Rickon killed.

It’s the WEIGHT of what this means to Davos. What he just realized is how much Sansa really means to Jon. Jon didn’t even throw a punch. And this stuns Davos.

Like Littlefinger, Davos finally gets it.

body:
Cripples, Bastards, and Broken Things

Game of Thrones S1E4 - the series really starts to settle in now that pretty much everyone is where they’re gonna be for the season:

  • “Lord” looks good on Robb
  • Tyrion just wants to make friends
  • Ned turning into Colombo to track down the bastards…because he lets Littlefinger lead him by the man bun
  • How old is Gendry? He’s a boy, but looks 30?
  • More Jon/Dany/Jon/Dany interplay. In this episode, our baby beans learn how to deal with bullies
  • BLR makes me see the jaust scene in a new light
  • I love season one Jon Snow so much
  • “Your brother Rhaegar was the last Dragon. Viserys is the shadow of a snake.”
  • Catelyn Stark: still awful.
